title: Idle

properties.name: description
properties.value: Idling, also known as being AFK (away from keyboard), describes time spent not interacting with the game. Idling does not necessarily mean the player is not playing the game, as many activities only require little attention, such as cutting trees for Woodcutting experience.

content:
Idling, also known as being AFK (away from keyboard), describes time spent not interacting with the game. Idling does not necessarily mean the player is not playing the game, as many activities only require little attention, such as cutting trees for Woodcutting experience.

There is a hidden timer that automatically logs out players who have been out-of-combat and idle for 5 minutes. Clicking the game, rotating the camera angle or even moving the cursor over an interactable object are deemed activities and will reset this counter.

After 6 hours of remaining logged into the same world, players will always be disconnected, even while in combat. Players will receive a warning of this five minutes beforehand.

Contents

  • 1 Combat timer
  • 2 Idle training methods
    • 2.1 Non-combat skills
    • 2.2 Combat skills
  • 3 Changes

Combat timer[edit | edit source]

Whenever a player attacks or is attacked, a combat timer will initiate. This timer lasts from the first hit until 10 seconds after the last hit is dealt. Characters are locked in combat during this time, and players cannot manually log out. If the game is forcefully closed or the player is disconnected by the 6-hour timer, their character will remain in combat for a full minute.

Combat itself also has an idle timer. When the player idles in combat for over 20 minutes, they will stop retaliating, even if Auto Retaliate is enabled in the Combat Options. Any interaction with the game will however reset this counter.

Idle training methods[edit | edit source]

There are many skilling activities that can be done effectively with infrequent interactions, and may even provide decent money making. Below are some of the most profitable ways of idling for every skill.

Non-combat skills[edit | edit source]

Farming - Extremely passive skill by itself. While trees provide the best experience, herbs are economically the most valuable.

Hunter - May be done passively with the use of birdhouses, which supply a steady income of valuable bird nests. More actively, but still rather idle, players can hunt Maniacal Monkeys and Herbiboars. These require little attention to hunt and grant considerable idle experience.

Herblore, Crafting, Fletching, Smithing and Cooking - Skills with few interactions. Usually by selecting All when prompted, players can convert an entire inventory of materials to a product of these skills. Players will only need to walk to the bank to deposit their inventory and collect new materials. Several of these idle activities such as smithing cannonballs and cooking fish will even be very lucrative.

Fishing - By far the best way of idling experience for this skill is by fishing karambwans, as they always appear in the same spot. This means the player will fish until either their inventory is full or they run out of raw karambwanji bait. Raising kittens while fishing is also a low effort way of earning death runes.

Woodcutting - Chopping trees that grant the most experience per log is the best way of idling this skill. With level 60 Woodcutting and 75% Hosidius favour, the player gains access to the Woodcutting Guild. This guild has a bank chest nearby high-level trees, allowing fast disposal of an inventory full of logs. Sulliusceps also offer great idle experience, but require the player to pay attention when moving through the swamp.

Magic - Can be idled without combat via certain utility spells, most notably Enchant Crossbow Bolt. Casting this once will autocast it on sets of ten bolts up to 10 times. This method is however very expensive. Casting teleportation spells, while not an idle activity, might be a more preferable non-combat way of training Magic. Plank Make becomes available at level 86, a cost-friendly spell that grants more overall experience than most other Magic spells. This spell autocasts until all logs in the inventory are converted to planks.

Prayer - Bones can be offered to altars as a mostly idle way of earning experience, as the player character slowly offers them one by one. The Gilded altar with lit incense burners in the player-owned house, and the Chaos Altar in level 38 Wilderness offer 3.5 times the normal rate of burying the bone. The Chaos Altar furthermore effectively doubles this amount to 7 times, as it holds a repeating 50% chance per bone to not consume it when offering.

Mining - The Motherlode Mine provides decent experience and payout for relatively few interactions. Pay-dirt veins only have a 33% chance of depleting per ore mined, instead of the usual guaranteed chance to deplete.

Firemaking - Can only be somewhat idled by battling the Wintertodt. Note that this is a dangerous activity that can possibly kill the player. It is recommended to enable sound effects to be aware when damage is taken, as this will also interupt most actions. If aiming for experience, this should be played on one of the officially dedicated Wintertodt worlds. Otherwise, this should be attempted solo or with few other players, to maximise the rewards earned each round (up to 13,500 points).

Agility and Thieving - Can hardly be idled. Still, in both cases is possible to keep the mouse cursor on the same location without moving it, for example by continuously crossing the pressure pads in the Brimhaven Agility Arena or pickpocketing trapped Knights of Ardougne. Note that most Agility and Thieving activities occassionally damage the player.

Runecraft - Cannot be idled well, as it requires running around a lot. From level 77, the player can craft blood and soul runes in Arceuus, which is partly AFK as it involves mining dense essence blocks. Making these runes is very profitable and also offers some Mining and Crafting experience.

Construction - Cannot be idled by conventional means, as building furniture is near instant. However, long bones and curved bones, which are rare drops from certain monsters, will provide passive Construction experience when handed in to Barlak.

Combat skills[edit | edit source]

Monsters with high Hitpoints but low offensive combat stats are best fought when idling combat. Ammonite Crabs are the most notable for this, with 100 Hitpoints and only one level in every other combat stat. Since they are always aggressive, the player can stand still in the same location. They will however become unaggressive after the player remains for 10 minutes in the area, after which the player needs to reset this timer by walking away a small distance.

It is worth noting that the Ammonite crabs cannot be damaged by the Dwarf Multicannon. Because of this, an alternative would be fighting Rock Crabs, which have 50 Hitpoints compared to the Ammonite Crabs. These are found in large quantities in multi-combat areas, allowing optimal use of the cannon. The player would only need to refill the cannon every while, and re-enter the area when the crabs become docile.

Another common option is idling in the Nightmare Zone, an activity that can even be done with multiple players. Players can spend a long time in this arena without ever taking damage from the bosses. They first bring down their Hitpoints to 1 with an Overload potion and dwarven rock cakes, then chuck Absorption potions to absorb a maximum of 1000 damage. Since enemies can only hit for one damage when the player has 1 health, and the absorption potions have no time limit, the player can absorb plenty of hits. To prevent regenerating health, flick Rapid Heal about every 50 seconds, since one hitpoint is passively regained every minute and Rapid Heal will reset this timer. Because of this, the Nightmare Zone requires slightly more attention than fighting crabs.

Lastly, players may wish to idle Slayer tasks, simultaneously training combat skills and Slayer. Depending on the task received, the monsters might be safespottable, causing the player to take no damage at all if done well. They may also be unaggressive to the player, in which case players with decent Hitpoints will not need to worry about dying when not paying attention.

Changes[edit | edit source]

Date Changes
10 September 2015
(update)

Players will now stop retaliating after 20 minutes of idle combat. This change was implemented secretly to reduce the effectiveness of splashing.
rawContent:
'''Idling''', also known as being '''AFK''' (away from keyboard), describes time spent not interacting with the game. Idling does not necessarily mean the player is not playing the game, as many activities only require little attention, such as cutting trees for [[Woodcutting]] experience.

There is a hidden timer that automatically logs out players who have been out-of-combat and idle for 5 minutes. Clicking the game, rotating the camera angle or even moving the cursor over an interactable object are deemed activities and will reset this counter.

After 6 hours of remaining logged into the same world, players will always be disconnected, even while in [[combat]]. Players will receive a warning of this five minutes beforehand.

==Combat timer==
Whenever a player attacks or is attacked, a combat timer will initiate. This timer lasts from the first hit until 10 seconds after the last hit is dealt. Characters are locked in combat during this time, and players cannot manually [[logout button|log out]]. If the game is forcefully closed or the player is disconnected by the 6-hour timer, their character will remain in combat for a full minute.

Combat itself also has an idle timer. When the player idles in combat for over 20 minutes, they will stop retaliating, even if ''Auto Retaliate'' is enabled in the [[Combat Options]]. Any interaction with the game will however reset this counter.

==Idle training methods==
There are many [[skilling]] activities that can be done effectively with infrequent interactions, and may even provide decent [[money making]]. Below are some of the most profitable ways of idling for every skill.

===Non-combat skills===
{{SCP|Farming}} '''[[Farming]]''' - Extremely passive skill by itself. While [[tree patch|trees]] provide the best experience, [[herb patch|herbs]] are economically the most valuable.

{{SCP|Hunter}} '''[[Hunter]]''' - May be done passively with the use of [[birdhouses]], which supply a steady income of valuable [[bird nest]]s. More actively, but still rather idle, players can hunt [[Maniacal monkey (Hunter)|Maniacal Monkeys]] and [[Herbiboars]]. These require little attention to hunt and grant considerable idle experience.

{{SCP|Herblore}} '''[[Herblore]], {{SCP|Crafting}} [[Crafting]], {{SCP|Fletching}} [[Fletching]], {{SCP|Smithing}} [[Smithing]]''' and {{SCP|Cooking}} '''[[Cooking]]''' - Skills with few interactions. Usually by selecting ''All'' when prompted, players can convert an entire inventory of materials to a product of these skills. Players will only need to walk to the bank to deposit their inventory and collect new materials. Several of these idle activities such as smithing [[cannonballs]] and cooking [[fish]] will even be very lucrative.

{{SCP|Fishing}} '''[[Fishing]]''' - By far the best way of idling experience for this skill is by fishing [[Raw karambwan|karambwan]]s, as they always appear in the same spot. This means the player will fish until either their inventory is full or they run out of [[raw karambwanji]] bait. Raising [[kitten]]s while fishing is also a low effort way of earning [[death runes]].

{{SCP|Woodcutting}} '''[[Woodcutting]]''' - Chopping trees that grant the most experience per log is the best way of idling this skill. With level 60 Woodcutting and 75% Hosidius [[favour]], the player gains access to the [[Woodcutting Guild]]. This guild has a [[bank chest]] nearby high-level trees, allowing fast disposal of an inventory full of logs. [[Sulliuscep]]s also offer great idle experience, but require the player to pay attention when moving through the [[Tar Swamp|swamp]].

{{SCP|Magic}} '''[[Magic]]''' - Can be idled without combat via certain utility spells, most notably [[Enchant Crossbow Bolt]]. Casting this once will autocast it on sets of ten bolts up to 10 times. This method is however very expensive. Casting [[teleportation spells]], while not an idle activity, might be a more preferable non-combat way of training Magic. [[Plank Make]] becomes available at level 86, a cost-friendly spell that grants more overall experience than most other Magic spells. This spell autocasts until all [[log (disambiguation)|logs]] in the inventory are converted to [[plank]]s.

{{SCP|Prayer}} '''[[Prayer]]''' - [[Bones]] can be offered to [[altar]]s as a mostly idle way of earning experience, as the player character slowly offers them one by one. The [[Gilded altar]] with lit [[incense burner]]s in the [[player-owned house]], and the [[Chaos temple (hut)|Chaos Altar]] in level 38 [[Wilderness]] offer 3.5 times the normal rate of burying the bone. The Chaos Altar furthermore effectively doubles this amount to 7 times, as it holds a repeating 50% chance per bone to not consume it when offering.

{{SCP|Mining}} '''[[Mining]]''' - The [[Motherlode Mine]] provides decent experience and payout for relatively few interactions. [[Pay-dirt]] veins only have a 33% chance of depleting per ore mined, instead of the usual guaranteed chance to deplete.

{{SCP|Firemaking}} '''[[Firemaking]]''' - Can only be somewhat idled by battling the [[Wintertodt]]. Note that this is a [[dangerous activity]] that can possibly kill the player. It is recommended to enable sound effects to be aware when damage is taken, as this will also interupt most actions. If aiming for experience, this should be played on one of the officially dedicated Wintertodt worlds. Otherwise, this should be attempted solo or with few other players, to maximise the rewards earned each round (up to 13,500 points).

{{SCP|Agility}} '''[[Agility]]''' and {{SCP|Thieving}} '''[[Thieving]]''' - Can hardly be idled. Still, in both cases is possible to keep the mouse cursor on the same location without moving it, for example by continuously crossing the [[pressure pad]]s in the [[Brimhaven Agility Arena]] or pickpocketing trapped [[Knights of Ardougne]]. Note that most Agility and Thieving activities occassionally damage the player.

{{SCP|Runecraft}} '''[[Runecraft]]''' - Cannot be idled well, as it requires running around a lot. From level 77, the player can craft [[blood rune|blood]] and [[soul rune]]s in [[Arceuus]], which is partly AFK as it involves mining [[dense essence block]]s. Making these runes is very profitable and also offers some Mining and Crafting experience.

{{SCP|Construction}} '''[[Construction]]''' - Cannot be idled by conventional means, as building furniture is near instant. However, [[long bone]]s and [[curved bone]]s, which are rare drops from certain monsters, will provide passive Construction experience when handed in to [[Barlak]].

===Combat skills===
Monsters with high [[Hitpoints]] but low offensive [[combat stats]] are best fought when idling combat. [[Ammonite Crab]]s are the most notable for this, with 100 Hitpoints and only one level in every other combat stat. Since they are always aggressive, the player can stand still in the same location. They will however become unaggressive after the player remains for 10 minutes in the area, after which the player needs to reset this timer by walking away a small distance.

It is worth noting that the Ammonite crabs cannot be damaged by the [[Dwarf Multicannon]]. Because of this, an alternative would be fighting [[Rock Crab]]s, which have 50 Hitpoints compared to the Ammonite Crabs. These are found in large quantities in multi-combat areas, allowing optimal use of the cannon. The player would only need to refill the cannon every while, and re-enter the area when the crabs become docile.

Another common option is idling in the [[Nightmare Zone]], an activity that can even be done with multiple players. Players can spend a long time in this arena without ever taking damage from the bosses. They first bring down their Hitpoints to 1 with an [[Overload (Nightmare Zone|Overload potion]] and [[dwarven rock cake]]s, then chuck [[Absorption potion]]s to absorb a maximum of 1000 damage. Since enemies can only hit for one damage when the player has 1 health, and the absorption potions have no time limit, the player can absorb plenty of hits. To prevent regenerating health, flick [[Rapid Heal]] about every 50 seconds, since one hitpoint is passively regained every minute and Rapid Heal will reset this timer. Because of this, the Nightmare Zone requires slightly more attention than fighting crabs.

Lastly, players may wish to idle [[Slayer tasks]], simultaneously training combat skills and [[Slayer]]. Depending on the task received, the monsters might be [[safespot]]table, causing the player to take no damage at all if done well. They may also be unaggressive to the player, in which case players with decent Hitpoints will not need to worry about dying when not paying attention.
